From Wikipedia:

... A powered flyby, or Oberth maneuver, describes a maneuver in which a rocket falls into a gravitational well, and then accelerates when its fall reaches maximum speed. The resulting maneuver is actually a more efficient way to gain kinetic energy than applying the same impulse outside of a gravitational well. The gain in efficiency is explained by the Oberth effect, a phenomenon that allows employing kinetic energy to generate greater mechanical energy. In practical terms, this means that the most efficient time for a spacecraft to burn its engine is at orbital periapse, when its orbital velocity (and so, its kinetic energy) is greatest.

Does this also apply to a braking burn, when I want to lower my apoapsis, or is then the Oberth effect actually inverse, i.e. I expend more energy at this periapsis in order to loose kinetic energy?

Edited July 29, 2015 by Falkenherz

The Oberth Effect benefits burns in both the prograde and retrograde directions. Capture burns are best done at low periapsis when speed is the greatest for this reason.

Edit: I wrote a little synopsis of the Oberth Effect and some of the common misconceptions about it here.
